 especially in some of the world&#8217;s most populous countries.&#160; Asia accounts for roughly 90% of global rice production and China is the world&#8217;s number one
        rice producer.&#160; Globally

      


 individual rice kernels are stored in common receiving locations such as farm silos for future delivery to grain dryers or area rice mills.&#160; At this stage
 large quantities of
        individual rice kernels are collectively called &#8220;paddy rice
&#8221; or &#8220;rough&#8221; rice.&#160; In this form
 the rice kernel is fully enveloped by the rice hull
 which serves as a protective cover

      


 if necessary
 paddy rice is cleaned of foreign material (scalping
 de-stoning and aspiration) before it enters the first stage of milling
 or paddy husking.&#160; In the paddy husker
 the hull is
        removed from rough rice by differential speed rubber rollers.&#160; Loosened hulls are carried off by aspiration.&#160; After husking
 a paddy separator uses a reciprocating motion to separate normal brown rice kernels (caryopsis) from unhusked kernels which

      


 the outer brown layers of bran are removed from the inner white starch endosperm by an abrasive or frictional milling process which produces a milled
 white rice kernel.&#160; After
        milling
 white rice is typically sorted by size to remove broken pieces of rice kernels from whole kernels
 as well as color sorting to remove discolored kernels.&#160; Additional stages may be required (per customer specifications) to polish the white

      


 testa
 nucellus and aleurone) surrounding the white starchy endosperm.&#160; Commercial rice bran makes up
        approximately 10% of rough rice by weight.&#160; Rice germ
 an especially nutrient rich material

      


 the oils present in raw rice bran come into contact with native lipase enzymes that are naturally present in the rice kernel.&#160; These lipase enzymes initiate a rapid enzymatic
        hydrolysis of the oil
 converting oils (triglycerides) into monoglycerides
 diglycerides and free fatty acids (FFA).&#160; As the FFA content builds in raw rice bran

      


        
        

          
        


 enzymatic degradation at normal room temperatures can increase the FFA levels to 5-8% within 24 hours and can continue at a rate of approximately 4-5% per day thereafter.&#160; Enzymatic degradation is
        the most serious form of degradation of raw rice bran.&#160; Rice bran stabilization is the process of carefully deactivating native enzymes to prevent the increase of FFA otherwise caused by lipase enzyme activity.&#160; Proper stabilization is critical in

      


 there have been a number of attempts to develop rice bran stabilization techniques
 including the use of chemicals
 microwave heating or variations of existing extrusion technology.&#160; Many of these

      


 broken rice
 raw bran
 SRB

      


 pearled barley
 milled oats
 steel-cut oats
 flaked oats
 hulls

      

      
      

      
      


 pressure and other conditions necessary to thoroughly deactivate enzymes without significantly damaging the structure or
        nutrient content of raw rice bran.&#160; This means that higher value compounds in bran
 such as oils

      


 on the premises of or in near proximity to any conventional rice mill so that freshly milled raw rice bran can be quickly delivered to our proprietary
        stabilizers.&#160; Process logic controllers maintain exact process conditions within the prescribed pressure/temperature regime.&#160; In case of power failure or interruption of the flow of fresh bran into the system
 the electronic control system is

 While we continue to meet with numerous participants in the U.S. rice milling industry to
                    expand our footprint with additional bran supplies
 in November 2018
 we acquired Golden Ridge Rice Mills in Wynne
 Arkansas
 to secure a company owned source of raw-bran and to strengthen our presence in the Delta region of the U.S.
                    which accounts for nearly 70% of the U.S. rice harvest and provides us with logistical benefits to serve our customers located east of the Rocky Mountains.&#160; In 2019 we invested in a significant expansion of the production capacity at
                    Golden Ridge and are constructing a bran room capable of producing new
 innovative
 and technology-driven SRB products. We also remain committed to building a strong presence in California
 which typically accounts for over 20% of the
                    U.S. rice harvest






      




              
                


 The acquisition of Golden Ridge Rice Mills was driven principally by our desire to secure a
                      cost-effective and secure source of raw bran in the Delta region of the U.S. However
 we also expect to grow our presence in the U.S. rice milling business through continued expansion of this facility and the possible acquisition of
                      other rice mills
 most likely in the Delta region and/or close to rice producing areas in California. We see the potential for this to lead to opportunities in the production of other products derived from rice and the by-products
                      created by rice milling including
 but not limited to
 rice flour
 rice protein
 rice starch
 soluble rice fiber
 defatted rice bran
 and rice bran oil. Ultimately
 we could become a consolidating force in the U.S. rice industry







      




              
                

 We have supplemented our strategy of vertical integration in the rice industry with the
                    acquisition of MGI Grain
 which specializes in processing barley
 oats and other small grains. These products are often purchased by the same buyers as our finished rice products from Golden Ridge and our SRB facilities. Our belief is
                    that we will be able to leverage this expansion of our product line into enhanced customer relationships and higher sales. Over the past year we have continued to strengthen our sales team to take advantage of our growing product line
                    and expanding geographic reach
 specifically by adding expertise in the area of small grain sales to complement our existing strengths in SRB sales. With this new team member now fully integrated the expertise is being cross pollinated






      




              
                

 We are focused on improving our operational efficiencies while driving cost and expense reductions.&#160; Absorption of our relatively
                    high fixed cost structure has been an historical issue for us
 and we hope to improve the economics of our business by driving greater volumes through our existing facilities
 and transitioning to lower cost company-owned facilities
                    such as Golden Ridge
 which should reduce our costs per unit of production over time.&#160; We have also embarked on an initiative to significantly reduce our corporate overhead in 2020. Key areas of focus with regard to this initiative
                    include planned reductions in headcount
 lessening our reliance on outside consultants
 and driving down administrative
 audit
 and legal expenses. In addition to lower operating expenses
 we expect 2020 cash flow to be positively

 such as SRB.&#160; We anticipate further incorporation of our food ingredients by major consumer packaged goods food companies as more food companies adopt rice bran as a standard

 enacted January 4
 2011
 amended the FDCA to significantly enhance the FDA&#8217;s authority over various aspects of food regulation.&#160; The FSMA granted the FDA mandatory recall
        authority when the FDA determines there is a reasonable probability that a food is adulterated or misbranded and that the use of
 or exposure to
 the food will cause serious adverse health consequences or death to humans or animals.&#160; One of the
        more significant changes under FSMA is the requirement of hazard analysis and risk-based preventive controls (HARPC) for all human and animal food processing facilities.&#160; We are committed to FSMA compliance and are SQF certified at all but one of
        our facilities

 and if we are unable to maintain effective internal control over financial reporting

 2018
 our management determined that we had material weaknesses in our internal control over financial reporting
 which
        related to our accounting for significant and complex acquisitions and equity transactions.&#160; We have concluded that these material weaknesses in our internal control over financial reporting was primarily due to the relocation from Arizona to Texas
        in 2018 which reduced our accounting personnel that have the appropriate level of experience and technical expertise to oversee the accounting and financial reporting requirements related to significant and complex acquisitions and equity
        transactions.&#160; As a result of these material weaknesses
 in 2019
 we initiated and implemented several remediation measures including
 but not limited to: hiring a CPA licensed Chief Accounting Officer
&#160; engaging third parties to (i) assist us in
        complying with the accounting and financial reporting requirements related to significant and complex acquisitions and equity transactions; and (ii) assist us with formalizing our business processes
 accounting policies and internal control
        documentation

 2019
 the United States experienced an outbreak of a novel coronavirus (COVID-19)

          the World Health Organization. This pandemic poses the risk that we or our customers
 suppliers and other business partners may be disrupted or prevented from conducting business activities for certain periods of time

 and all
          employees have been trained on COVID-19 by our Occupational Health &amp; Safety Manager
 as well as being cross-trained to backfill in one another&#8217;s absence in accordance with GFSI requirements. We are also limiting visitors to all facilities
          have cancelled all non-essential travel
 and shifted many employees to working remotely. Our employees have been reporting to work
 either remotely or in-person
 without any material changes in attendance or resulting changes in our productivity
          due to the COVID-19 outbreak. We currently do not expect any of our facilities to be subject to government-mandated closures. The COVID-19 outbreak has not yet caused any material disruption in the supply of raw materials used in our products or

        


 which we expect will adversely affect the demand
          for our products. However

 including the related impact on our customers&#8217; spending

        financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities
 disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities and the reported amounts of revenues and
        expenses.&#160; These estimates and assumptions are affected by the application of our accounting policies.&#160; Our significant accounting policies are described in Note 2 to our Consolidated Financial Statements.&#160; Critical accounting estimates are those
        that require application of management&#8217;s most difficult
 subjective or complex judgments
 often as a result of matters that are inherently uncertain and may change in subsequent periods.&#160; While we apply our judgment based on assumptions believed to
        be reasonable under the circumstances
 actual results could vary from these assumptions.&#160; It is possible that materially different amounts would be reported using different assumptions.&#160; The following is a description of what we consider to be our

      

Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value
 with cost determined by the first-in
 first-out method.&#160; We employ a full absorption
        procedure using standard cost techniques for the majority of our operations.&#160; The standards are customarily reviewed and adjusted so that they are materially consistent with actual purchase and production costs.&#160; Provisions for potentially obsolete
        or slow-moving inventory are made based upon our analysis of inventory levels
 historical obsolescence and future sales forecasts

      

 &#8211; Property and equipment are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation.&#160; Depreciation is computed on the straight-line basis over the estimated useful

      


        
        

          
        

We review our long-lived assets
 such as property and equipment
 operating lease assets
 and right-of-use assets
 for impairment whenever
        events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.&#160; An impairment loss is recognized when the undiscounted future cash flows estimated to be generated by the asset to be held and used are not
        sufficient to recover the unamortized balance of the asset.&#160; An impairment loss is recognized based on the difference between the carrying values and estimated fair value.&#160; The estimated fair value is determined based on either the discounted
        future cash flows or other appropriate fair value methods with the amount of any such deficiency charged to operations in the current year.&#160; Estimates of future cash flows are based on many factors
 including current operating results
 expected
        market trends and competitive influences.&#160; Assets to be disposed of by sale are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair value

      

 &#8211; Goodwill is recorded when the purchase price paid for an acquisition exceeds the estimated fair value of net identified tangible and intangible
        assets acquired.&#160; Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level on an annual basis in the fourth quarter and between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more likely than not reduce the fair value of
        the reporting unit below its carrying value.&#160; We may first perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value.&#160; If we conclude that is the case
        or chose to not perform the qualitative assessment
 we quantify the reporting unit&#8217;s fair value.&#160; If the carrying amount of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value
 we will record an impairment loss based on the difference.&#160; The impairment loss
        will be limited to the amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit.&#160; Multiple valuation techniques may be used to assess the fair value of the reporting unit.&#160; All of these techniques include the use of estimates and assumptions that are
        inherently uncertain.&#160; Changes in these estimates and assumptions could materially affect the determination of fair value or goodwill impairment

      

Intangible Assets

 exclusive of goodwill
 are amortized over the useful lives of the assets unless that life is determined
        to be indefinite.&#160; All of our intangible assets
 exclusive of goodwill
 are finite lived.&#160; We evaluate the remaining useful life of an intangible asset each reporting period to determine whether events or circumstances may indicate that a revision
        to the useful life is warranted to reflect the remaining expected use of the asset.&#160; If an intangible asset&#8217;s useful life is determined to be finite
 but the precise length of that life is not known
 the intangible asset is amortized over our best
        estimate of the asset&#8217;s useful life in a manner that reflects the pattern in which the asset&#8217;s economic benefits are consumed or expected to be realized.&#160; We review our long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances
        indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.&#160; An impairment loss is recognized when the undiscounted future cash flows estimated to be generated by the asset to be held and used are not sufficient to recover the unamortized
        balance of the asset.&#160; Our primary intangible asset
 exclusive of goodwill
 is a customer relationship intangible which was recognized in the acquisition of MGI and derives its value from future cash flows expected from the customers acquired from
        MGI.&#160; Changes in the actual or estimated cash flows of these customers could result in a material adjustment to amortization expense
 an impairment loss
 or both.&#160; Estimates of future cash flows are based on many factors
 including current cash
        flows

      

 &#8211; We account for a contract with a customer when the written contract is committed
 the rights of the parties
 including payment terms
 are identified
 the
 contracts which
        contain a single performance obligation

We recognize revenue at the point in time that control of the ordered product(s) is transferred to the customer
 which is upon
          delivery to the customer
 or its designee at our location
 a customer location or other customer-designated delivery point.&#160; For substantially all of our contracts
 control of the ordered product(s) transfers at our location.&#160; Amounts invoiced to
          customers for shipping and handling are reported as revenues and the related costs incurred to deliver product to the customer are reported as cost of goods sold.
      

Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration we expect to receive in exchange for fulfilling product orders.&#160; Incidental items that are immaterial in the context of the contract

 including
 for example
 rebates and volume discounts
 or

 including costs for rebates and discounts.&#160; If the
          consideration promised in a contract includes a variable amount

 the FASB issued ASU No. 2018-07
.&#160; The guidance was issued to simplify the accounting for share-based transactions by expanding the scope of Topic 718 from only being applicable to share-based payments to
            employees to also include share-based payment transactions for acquiring goods and services from nonemployees.&#160; As a result
 nonemployee share-based transactions are measured by estimating the fair value of the equity instruments at the grant
            date
 taking into consideration the probability of satisfying performance conditions. We adopted ASU 2018-07 on January 1
 2019.&#160; The guidance did not change the way we recognize expense for director awards.&#160; Adoption of the standard only
            impacted the recognition of expense
 on a prospective basis
 for one supplier&#8217;s awards which were subject to performance conditions.&#160; Adoption of the guidance did not have a material impact on our financial statements in 2019.&#160; Additional
            disclosures required by the guidance are presented within the &#8220;Share-Based Compensation&#8221; policy disclosure below
        

        
        

 &#8211; The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in U.S. dollars and in accordance with
          accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (GAAP). The preparation of the consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets
          and liabilities
 disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses.&#160; Actual results may differ from those estimates.&#160; The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of

        

 &#8211; The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of
          assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period.&#160; Because of the uncertainty inherent in such estimates

        


          
          

            
          



            
            


        

        
        

 &#8211; We consider all highly liquid investments purchased with an original maturity of three months or less at the time of purchase to be cash
          equivalents.&#160; In all periods presented
 we maintained our cash and cash equivalents with major banks.&#160; We maintain cash in bank accounts in amounts which at times may exceed federally insured limits. At times we invest in money market funds which

        

 &#8211; Accounts receivable represent amounts receivable on trade accounts.&#160; The allowance for doubtful accounts is based on
          our assessment of the collectability of customer accounts and the aging of accounts receivable.&#160; We analyze the aging of customer accounts
 customer concentrations
 customer creditworthiness
 current economic trends and changes in our customer
          payment patterns when evaluating the adequacy of the allowance for doubtful accounts.&#160; From period to period
 differences in judgments or estimates utilized may result in material differences in the amount and timing of the provision for doubtful

        

Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value.&#160; We employ a full absorption procedure using standard cost techniques for the majority of
          our operations.&#160; The standards are customarily reviewed and adjusted so that they are materially consistent with actual purchase and production costs.&#160; Provisions for potentially obsolete or slow-moving inventory are made based upon our analysis
          of inventory levels
 historical obsolescence and future sales forecasts

        

 &#8211; Property and equipment are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation.&#160; Depreciation is computed on the straight-line basis over the estimated

        


          undiscounted future cash flows estimated to be generated by the asset to be held and used are not sufficient to recover the unamortized balance of the asset.&#160; An impairment loss is recognized based on the difference between the carrying value and
          estimated fair value.&#160; The estimated fair value is determined based on either the discounted future cash flows or other appropriate fair value methods with the amount of any indicated deficiency charged to operations in the current year.&#160;
          Estimates of future cash flows are based on many factors
 including current operating results
 expected market trends and competitive influences.&#160; Assets to be disposed of by sale are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair value

        

 &#8211; Goodwill is recorded when the purchase price paid for an acquisition exceeds the estimated fair value of net identified tangible and intangible assets acquired.&#160;
          Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level on an annual basis in the fourth quarter and between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more likely than not reduce the fair value of the reporting unit
          below its carrying value.&#160; We may first perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value.&#160; If we conclude that is the case
 or chose to not
          perform the qualitative assessment
 we quantify the reporting unit&#8217;s fair value.&#160; If the carrying amount of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value
 we record an impairment loss based on the difference.&#160; The impairment loss will be limited to
          the amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit.&#160; Multiple valuation techniques may be used to assess the fair value of the reporting unit.&#160; All of these techniques include the use of estimates and assumptions that are inherently
          uncertain.&#160; Changes in these estimates and assumptions could materially affect the determination of fair value or goodwill impairment

        


          
          

            
          



            
            


        

Intangible Assets

 exclusive of goodwill
 are amortized over the useful lives of the assets unless that life is
          determined to be indefinite.&#160; All of our intangible assets
 exclusive of goodwill
 are finite lived.&#160; We evaluate the remaining useful life of an intangible asset each reporting period to determine whether events or circumstances may indicate
          that a revision to the useful life is warranted to reflect the remaining expected use of the asset.&#160; If an intangible asset&#8217;s useful life is determined to be finite
 but the precise length of that life is not known
 the intangible asset is
          amortized over our best estimate of the asset&#8217;s useful life in a manner that reflects the pattern in which the asset&#8217;s economic benefits are consumed or expected to be realized.&#160; We review our long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or
          changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.&#160; An impairment loss is recognized when the undiscounted future cash flows estimated to be generated by the asset to be held and used are not sufficient
          to recover the unamortized balance of the asset.&#160; Our primary intangible asset
 exclusive of goodwill
 is a customer relationship intangible which derives its value from future cash flows expected from the acquired customers.&#160; Changes in the
          actual or estimated future cash flows of these customers could result in a material adjustment to amortization expense
 an impairment loss
 or both.&#160; Estimates of future cash flows are based on many factors
 including current cash flows
 expected

 with adoption of ASU 2016-02 and related guidance (discussed further above under

        


 land and corporate office space under operating leases with monthly or annual rent payments.&#160; We lease certain machinery and equipment under finance leases with monthly rent payments.&#160;
          We determine if an arrangement is a lease at inception.&#160; Operating lease assets are presented as operating lease right-of-use assets and the related liabilities are presented as operating lease liabilities in our consolidated balance sheets.&#160;
          Finance lease right-of-use assets are included in property and equipment
 net

        


 beginning at the commencement date
 for leases exceeding a year.&#160; Minimum
          lease payments include the fixed lease components of the lease and any variable rate payments that depend on an index
 initially measured using the index at the lease commencement date.&#160; Lease terms may include options to renew when it is
          reasonably certain that we will exercise that option.&#160; We combine lease and nonlease components and account for them as a single lease component.&#160; Certain leases contain rent escalation clauses
 rent holidays
 capital improvement funding or other

        


 we apply a discount rate to the minimum lease payments within each lease.&#160; When we cannot readily determine the discount rate implicit in a lease
 we
          utilize our incremental borrowing rate
 the rate of interest that we would incur to borrow
 on a collateralized basis over a similar term
 an amount equal to the lease payments in a similar economic environment.&#160; To estimate the incremental
          borrowing rate

        


 we recognize amortization expense related to the minimum lease payments
          on a straight-line basis over the lease term while interest expense is recognized using the effective interest method.&#160; Expense related to variable lease payments that do not depend on a rate or index and short-term rentals
 on leases with terms
          less than a year

 &#8211; We account for income taxes by recording a deferred tax asset or liability for the recognition of future deductible or taxable amounts and operating loss and

        


          
          

            
          



            
            


        


          assets are recognized for deductible temporary differences and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.&#160; A valuation allowance is established

Fair value is based on the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction
            between market participants at the measurement date.&#160; Certain assets and liabilities may be presented in the financial statements at fair value.&#160; Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis may include property and
            equipment.
        

        
        




                
                  

                  

                    








                
                  

                  











                
                  

                  

                    





        



        

        
        

        
        

On April 4
 2019
 we acquired substantially all of the assets comprising the business of MGI Grain Processing
 LLC
 a Minnesota limited liability company
            now conducting business as MGI Grain Incorporated (MGI) for an aggregate purchase price of $3.8 million.&#160; The purchase price included $0.3 million deposited in an escrow account at closing which was subsequently released to the sellers in June
            2019.&#160; MGI owns and operates a grain mill and processing facility in East Grand Forks

          combination.&#160; The results of MGI&#8217;s operations are included in our consolidated financial statements beginning April 4
 2019.&#160; In 2019

 our appraiser finalized certain fair value calculations and we completed our review of the calculations.&#160; The fair value of MGI&#8217;s trade receivables at acquisition
 equaled the gross
          amount of trade receivables.&#160; The fair value of the customer relationship intangible at acquisition was estimated using an income approach based on expected future cash flows.&#160; As discussed in Note 9
 we are amortizing the customer relationship
          intangible to expense over the 15-year period of expected future economic benefit

            primarily was attributed to intangible assets that do not qualify for separate recognition and synergies generated by MGI when combined with our existing operations.&#160; The $0.7 million allocated to goodwill is deductible for tax purposes over
            the next fifteen years.

 we completed the sale of the assets of Healthy Natural (HN) for $18.3 million in cash and recognized a gain on sale of $8.2 million
 net of $4.7 million in taxes.&#160; The selling price was subject to

          in 2017 was based on an estimated working capital adjustment of $0.3 million
 which was disputed.&#160; Our consolidated balance sheets included a liability for the settlement of the working capital adjustment of $0.3 million as of December 31
 2018.&#160;

 2019

 and increased the estimated working capital adjustment from $0.3 million to $0.5 million.&#160; We paid the $0.5 million liability in July 2019. The
          adjustment to lower the gain on the sale of HN as a result of the change in the estimated working capital adjustment is recorded in discontinued operations in 2019

 we entered into a factoring agreement which provides for a $7.0 million credit facility with a lender.&#160; We may only borrow to the extent we have qualifying accounts receivable as defined in the agreement.&#160; The facility has
            an initial two-year term and automatically renews for successive annual periods
 unless proper termination notice is given.&#160; We paid a $0.2 million facility fee upon inception of the agreement which is amortizing to interest expense on a
            straight-line basis over two years. &#160;We incur recurring fees under the agreement
 including a funding fee of 0.5% above the prime rate
 in no event to be less than 5.5%
 on any advances and a service fee on average net funds borrowed.&#160; During
            2019
 we expensed $0.1 million of interest and fees under the agreement.&#160; In 2019
 fees incurred averaged 6.7% (exclusive of deferred cost amortization) and interest averaged 8.2% of the amounts outstanding under the facility.&#160; In 2019
            outstanding borrowings under the agreement averaged $0.2 million per day.&#160; As of December&#160;31
&#160;2019
 the $1.8&#160;million presented on our consolidated balance sheets as due under the factoring agreement consisted of $2.0 million borrowed net of
            $0.2 million of unamortized debt issuance costs.&#160; Amortization of debt issuance costs in 2019
 was less than $0.1 million.&#160; The lender has the right to demand repayment of the advances at any time.&#160; The lender has a security interest in

 2019
 net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards for U.S. federal tax purposes totaled $31.4 million.&#160; Effective with the 2017 Tax Act in December 2017
NOLs generated after December 31
 2017
 do not expire.&#160; Federal NOLs of $9.9 million expire at various dates from 2020 through 2037 and federal NOLs of $21.5 million do not expire.&#160; NOL carryforwards for state tax purposes
          totaled $40.6 million at December 31

        


          value our equity in September 2017.&#160; Our ability to utilize previously accumulated NOL carryforwards is subject to substantial annual limitations due to the change in ownership provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986
 as amended
 and
          similar state regulations.&#160; In general
 the annual limitation is equal to the value of the stock of the corporation immediately before the ownership change
 multiplied by the long-term tax-exempt rate for the month in which the ownership change
          occurs.&#160; Any unused annual limitation may generally be carried over to later years until the NOL carryforwards expire.&#160; We completed a formal analysis for the taxable year 2017 to determine the amount of annual limitation on net operations loss
          carryforwards prior to utilization.&#160; The study resulted in a substantial annual limitation on the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards generated before September 13
 2017.&#160; Accordingly
 we have reduced our net operating loss
          carryforwards by $13.7 million to reflect these limitations.&#160; On November 28
 2017
 Nutra S.A. LLC (Nutra SA) redeemed our entire membership interest in Nutra SA which resulted in generating a capital loss of $29.6 million for federal tax
          purposes.&#160; Of this
 $23.6 million is subject to an IRC Section 382 annual limitation of $0.3 million.&#160; We have determined it is more likely than not that all of the capital loss subject to the IRC Section 382 limitation will expire unused.&#160;
          Accordingly

        


          are open for audit by the IRS for years after 2015 and

 Recognized Identifiable Assets Acquired and Liabilities Assumed
 Property
 Plant

  


 2019
 we acquired substantially all of the assets comprising the business of MGI Grain Processing
 LLC
 a Minnesota limited liability company
 now conducting business as MGI Grain Incorporated (MGI) for an aggregate purchase price of $3.8 million.&amp;#160; The purchase price included $0.3 million deposited in an escrow account at closing which was subsequently released to the sellers in June 2019.&amp;#160; MGI owns and operates a grain mill and processing facility in East Grand Forks
 Minnesota. &lt;/font&gt;We acquired MGI as part of our strategy to expand our product portfolio. &amp;#160;The acquisition has been accounted for as a business combination.&amp;#160; The results of MGI&amp;#8217;s operations are included in our consolidated financial statements beginning April 4
 2019.&amp;#160; In 2019
 we incurred $0.1 million of MGI acquisition-related costs which are included in selling
 general and administrative expenses.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;The purchase price for MGI was subject to adjustment if the estimated closing working capital with respect to the assets purchased and the liabilities assumed was different than the actual closing working capital
 as defined in the purchase agreement.&amp;#160; The seller of MGI paid a working capital adjustment of $18 thousand in 2019.The following table summarizes the purchase price allocation
 the consideration transferred to acquire MGI and the amounts of identified assets acquired and liabilities assumed (in thousands). &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; color: #000000; width: 100%;&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td valign=bottom style=vertical-align: top; padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=2 nowrap=nowrap style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: 2px solid rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: center;&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;Estimated at&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;June 30

width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;In the fourth quarter of 2019
 our appraiser finalized certain fair value calculations and we completed our review of the calculations.&amp;#160; The fair value of MGI&amp;#8217;s trade receivables at acquisition
 equaled the gross amount of trade receivables.&amp;#160; The fair value of the customer relationship intangible at acquisition was estimated using an income approach based on expected future cash flows.&amp;#160; As discussed in Note 9
 we are amortizing the customer relationship intangible to expense over the 15-year period of expected future economic benefit
 in proportion to the discounted expected future cash flows used to estimate the value of the intangible at acquisition&lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;.&amp;#160; Goodwill primarily was attributed to intangible assets that do not qualify for separate recognition and synergies generated by MGI when combined with our existing operations.&amp;#160; The $0.7 million allocated to goodwill is deductible for tax purposes over the next fifteen years.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;Our revenues for 2019 include $1.9 million related to the acquired MGI business.&amp;#160; Our net loss for 2019 includes $0.3 million of net loss from the acquired MGI business.&amp;#160; T&lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;he following table provides unaudited &lt;/font&gt;pro forma information for the periods presented as if the MGI acquisition had occurred January&amp;#160;1

 2018
 or of our future operating results.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify; font-weight: bold;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Golden Ridge&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;In November 2018
 we acquired substantially all of the assets comprising the business of Golden Ridge Rice Mills
 LLC
 now conducting business as Golden Ridge Rice Mills
 Inc. (Golden Ridge).&amp;#160; The primary activity of the business is the operation of a &lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;rice mill in Wynne
 Arkansas. &lt;/font&gt;&amp;#160;We acquired the business as part of our strategy to vertically integrate in order to leverage our proprietary technologies for producing SRB and derivative products. &amp;#160;The acquisition has been accounted for as a business combination.&amp;#160; The results of Golden Ridge&amp;#8217;s operations are included in our consolidated financial statements beginning November 28
 2018.&amp;#160; In 2018
 we incurred $0.1 million of Golden Ridge acquisition-related costs which are included in selling
 general and administrative expenses.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;The purchase price for Golden Ridge was subject to adjustment if the estimated working capital with respect to the assets purchased and the liabilities assumed at the time of closing was different than the actual closing working capital
 as defined in the purchase agreement.&amp;#160; We revised our preliminary estimate of the working capital adjustment as indicated in the table below.The following table summarizes the purchase price allocation as of closing and as revised (in thousands
 except share and per share amounts). &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; color: #000000; width: 100%;&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td valign=bottom style=vertical-align: top; padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=2 nowrap=nowrap style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: 2px solid rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: center;&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;Estimated at&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;Acquisition and as of&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;December 31
 2018&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap style=text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom; padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-bottom: 2px; text-align: center;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=2 nowrap=nowrap style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: 2px solid rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: center;&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;Adjustments&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap style=text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom; padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-bottom: 2px; text-align: center;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=2 nowrap=nowrap style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: 2px solid rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: center;&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;Final as of&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&gt;December 31

178&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify; color: #000000;&gt;The 1
666
667 shares issued at closing of our purchase of Golden Ridge included 380
952 shares that were deposited in an escrow account to be used to satisfy any indemnification obligations of the seller that may arise.&amp;#160; As of December 31
 2018
 the 380
952 shares remained in escrow.&amp;#160; In July 2019
 we reached an agreement to settle the $0.6 million working capital adjustment receivable and other claims with the sellers of Golden Ridge.&amp;#160; As a result
 (i) 340
000 shares of common stock held in the escrow account ($1.0 million fair value as of both the settlement date and the November 28
 2018
 acquisition date) were returned to us and retired
 (ii) the remaining $0.4 million note payable we owed to a seller was cancelled and (iii) certain open grain purchase contracts with entities related to a seller were terminated.&amp;#160; We recorded a gain on the noncash settlement of $0.8 million in the third quarter of 2019
 which is included in other income. In connection with the foregoing
 a settlement agreement was entered into among the parties
 all shares of common stock were distributed
 and the escrow agreement was terminated.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify; color: #000000;&gt;The fair value of trade receivables for Golden Ridge at acquisition was $1.6 million
 which was $0.1 million less than the value of gross trade receivables.&amp;#160; Goodwill was primarily attributed to intangible assets that do not qualify for separate recognition and synergies generated by Golden Ridge&amp;#8217;s integration with our other operations.&amp;#160; Between December 31
 2018
 and June 30
 2019
 information was discovered requiring adjustments to the opening balance sheet of Golden Ridge.&amp;#160; The adjustments resulted primarily from an overstatement of the opening balances of commodities payable and accounts payable at December 31
 2018.&amp;#160; These balances were adjusted in the June 30
 2019
 financial statements.&amp;#160; The impact of the adjustments to our prior period financial statements is not considered significant.&amp;#160; No additional adjustments have been made to the opening balances after June 30
 2019.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;&lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;Our revenues for 2019 and 2018 includes $7.6 million and $0.9 million related to the acquired Golden Ridge business.&amp;#160; Our net loss for 2019 and 2018 includes $2.8 million and $0.2 million
 respectively
 related to the acquired Golden Ridge business.&amp;#160; The following table provides unaudited &lt;/font&gt;pro forma information for 2018 as if the acquisition had occurred January 1
 2017.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;table align=center border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=width: 70%; color: #000000; font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left;&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td valign=bottom style=vertical-align: top; width: 58%; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-indent: -9pt; margin-left: 9pt;&gt;Revenues (in thousands)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;$&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right; width: 9%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;30

 we entered into $0.3 million of firm purchase commitments related to capital projects.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify; font-weight: bold;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Employment Contracts and Severance Payments&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;In the normal course of business
 we periodically enter into employment agreements which incorporate indemnification provisions.&amp;#160; While the maximum amount to which we may be exposed under such agreements cannot be reasonably estimated
 we maintain insurance coverage
 which we believe will effectively mitigate our obligations under these indemnification provisions.&amp;#160; No amounts have been recorded in our financial statements with respect to any obligations under such agreements.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;We have employment contracts with certain officers and key management that include provisions for potential severance payments in the event of without-cause terminations or terminations under certain circumstances after a change in control. In addition
 vesting of outstanding nonvested equity grants would accelerate following a change in control.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify; font-weight: bold;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Legal Matters&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;From time to time we are involved in litigation incidental to the conduct of our business.&amp;#160; These matters may relate to employment and labor claims
 patent and intellectual property claims
 claims of alleged non-compliance with contract provisions and claims related to alleged violations of laws and regulations.&amp;#160; When applicable
 we record accruals for contingencies when it is probable that a liability will be incurred and the amount of loss can be reasonably estimated.&amp;#160; While the outcome of lawsuits and other proceedings against us cannot be predicted with certainty
 in the opinion of management
 individually or in the aggregate

 we entered into a factoring agreement which provides for a $7.0 million credit facility with a lender.&amp;#160; We may only borrow to the extent we have qualifying accounts receivable as defined in the agreement.&amp;#160; The facility has an initial two-year term and automatically renews for successive annual periods
 unless proper termination notice is given.&amp;#160; We paid a $0.2 million facility fee upon inception of the agreement which is amortizing to interest expense on a straight-line basis over two years.&amp;#160; We incur recurring fees under the agreement
 including a funding fee of 0.5% above the prime rate
 in no event to be less than 5.5%
 on any advances and a service fee on average net funds borrowed.&amp;#160; During 2019
 we expensed $0.1 million of interest and fees under the agreement.&amp;#160; In 2019
 fees incurred averaged 6.7% (exclusive of deferred cost amortization) and interest averaged 8.2% of the amounts outstanding under the facility.&amp;#160; In 2019
 outstanding borrowings under the agreement averaged $0.2 million per day.&amp;#160; As of December 31
 2019
 the $1.8 million presented on our consolidated balance sheets as due under the factoring agreement consisted of $2.0 million borrowed net of $0.2 million of unamortized debt issuance costs.&amp;#160; Amortization of debt issuance costs in 2019

 in the acquisition of Golden Ridge
 at the present value of future payments using a discount rate of 4.8%
 which we determined approximated the market rate for similar debt with similar maturities as of the date of acquisition.&amp;#160; Payable in monthly installments.  we borrowed under a demand loan collateralized by the investment in the money market fund described in Note 5
 at amounts and rates determined at the discretion of the lender.&amp;#160; Borrowing under the loan averaged $0.1 million in 2019 and interest averaged 5.5%. At December 31

 Gain (Loss) on Disposal of Discontinued Operation

  

 Including Discontinued Operation

  


 we completed the sale of the assets of Healthy Natural (HN) for $18.3 million in cash and recognized a gain on sale of $8.2 million
 net of $4.7 million in taxes.&amp;#160; The selling price was subject to adjustment if the estimated closing working capital with respect to the assets sold and the liabilities assumed was different than the actual closing working capital for those assets and liabilities.&amp;#160; The $8.2 million net gain on sale recognized in 2017 was based on an estimated working capital adjustment of $0.3 million
 which was disputed.&amp;#160; Our consolidated balance sheets included a liability for the settlement of the working capital adjustment of $0.3 million as of December 31
 2018.&amp;#160; During the three months ended March 31
 2019
 we finalized the adjustment with the purchaser of HN
 and increased the estimated working capital adjustment from $0.3 million to $0.5 million.&amp;#160; We paid the $0.5 million liability in July 2019. The adjustment to lower the gain on the sale of HN as a result of the change in the estimated working capital adjustment is recorded in discontinued operations in 2019
 net of zero tax benefit.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;Restricted cash on our consolidated balance sheets as of December 31
 2018



  

  

  


 warrants
 nonvested shares and restricted stock units that vest solely on the basis of a service condition are calculated using the treasury stock method.&amp;#160; The dilutive effects of the outstanding preferred stock are calculated using the if-converted method.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;Below are reconciliations of the numerators and denominators in the EPS computations
 and information on potentially dilutive securities.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=font-family: 'Times New Roman';  end of period&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;$&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right; width: 9%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;3

 excluding goodwill

text-align: right; width: 9%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;16&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;The customer relationship intangible
 acquired from MGI in 2019
 is amortizing over the 15-year period of expected future economic benefit
 in proportion to the discounted expected future cash flows used to estimate the value of the intangible at acquisition.&amp;#160; It is amortizing at a more rapid rate in the earlier periods than in later periods.&amp;#160; Other finite-lived intangible assets are amortizing on a straight-line basis.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;As of December 31
 2019


 Goodwill


 or chose to not perform the qualitative assessment
 we quantify the reporting unit&amp;#8217;s fair value.&amp;#160; If the carrying amount of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value
 we record an impairment loss based on the difference.&amp;#160; The impairment loss will be limited to the amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit.&amp;#160; Multiple valuation techniques may be used to assess the fair value of the reporting unit.&amp;#160; All of these techniques include the use of estimates and assumptions that are inherently uncertain.&amp;#160; Changes in these estimates and assumptions could materially affect the determination of fair value or goodwill impairment


  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

 Intangible Assets


 exclusive of goodwill&lt;/font&gt; &amp;#8211; Recognized intangible assets
 exclusive of goodwill
 are amortized over the useful lives of the assets unless that life is determined to be indefinite.&amp;#160; All of our intangible assets
 exclusive of goodwill
 are finite lived.&amp;#160; We evaluate the remaining useful life of an intangible asset each reporting period to determine whether events or circumstances may indicate that a revision to the useful life is warranted to reflect the remaining expected use of the asset.&amp;#160; If an intangible asset&amp;#8217;s useful life is determined to be finite
 but the precise length of that life is not known
 the intangible asset is amortized over our best estimate of the asset&amp;#8217;s useful life in a manner that reflects the pattern in which the asset&amp;#8217;s economic benefits are consumed or expected to be realized.&amp;#160; We review our long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.&amp;#160; An impairment loss is recognized when the undiscounted future cash flows estimated to be generated by the asset to be held and used are not sufficient to recover the unamortized balance of the asset.&amp;#160; Our primary intangible asset
 exclusive of goodwill
 is a customer relationship intangible which derives its value from future cash flows expected from the acquired customers.&amp;#160; Changes in the actual or estimated future cash flows of these customers could result in a material adjustment to amortization expense
 an impairment loss
 or both.&amp;#160; Estimates of future cash flows are based on many factors
 including current cash flows


  

  


  


  

  

  


  


  

  

  

  

  

 Net of Tax

  

 Net of Tax

  


 2017
 and has several key provisions impacting the accounting for and reporting of income taxes. The most significant provision reduced the U.S. corporate statutory tax rate from 35% to 21% beginning on January 1
 2018. We remeasured the applicable deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the rates at which they are expected to reverse. As a result
 the gross deferred tax assets and liabilities were adjusted which resulted in an expense for income taxes of $7.1 million which was fully offset by a corresponding change to our valuation allowance in 2017. &lt;font style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0);&gt;The Tax Act contains several base broadening provisions that became effective on January 1
 2018
 that did not have a material impact on 2018 and 2019 earnings.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Deferred tax asset (liability) is comprised of the following (in thousands):&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;table align=center border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=width: 50%;  end of year&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;$&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right; width: 9%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;8
687&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;$&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right; width: 9%; border-bottom: 4px double rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;5
398&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 4px; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;As of December 31
 2019
 net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards for U.S. federal tax purposes totaled $31.4 million.&amp;#160; Effective with the 2017 Tax Act in December 2017
&lt;font style=background-color: #FFFFFF; color: #000000;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;NOLs generated after December 31
 2017
 do not expire.&amp;#160; Federal NOLs of $9.9 million expire at various dates from 2020 through 2037 and federal NOLs of $21.5 million do not expire.&amp;#160; NOL carryforwards for state tax purposes totaled $40.6 million at December 31
 2019 and expire at various dates from 2020 through 2039.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;We experienced several ownership changes as defined in IRC Section 382(g) as a result of offerings and conversions that occurred in 2013 and 2014 and a new shareholder obtaining a greater than 5% interest in the value our equity in September 2017.&amp;#160; Our ability to utilize previously accumulated NOL carryforwards is subject to substantial annual limitations due to the change in ownership provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986
 as amended
 and similar state regulations.&amp;#160; In general
 the annual limitation is equal to the value of the stock of the corporation immediately before the ownership change
 multiplied by the long-term tax-exempt rate for the month in which the ownership change occurs.&amp;#160; Any unused annual limitation may generally be carried over to later years until the NOL carryforwards expire.&amp;#160; We completed a formal analysis for the taxable year 2017 to determine the amount of annual limitation on net operations loss carryforwards prior to utilization.&amp;#160; The study resulted in a substantial annual limitation on the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards generated before September 13
 2017.&amp;#160; Accordingly
 we have reduced our net operating loss carryforwards by $13.7 million to reflect these limitations.&amp;#160; On November 28
 2017
 Nutra S.A. LLC (Nutra SA) redeemed our entire membership interest in Nutra SA which resulted in generating a capital loss of $29.6 million for federal tax purposes.&amp;#160; Of this
 $23.6 million is subject to an IRC Section 382 annual limitation of $0.3 million.&amp;#160; We have determined it is more likely than not that all of the capital loss subject to the IRC Section 382 limitation will expire unused.&amp;#160; Accordingly
 we have not recognized the deferred tax asset associated with the IRC Section 382 limited capital loss.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;We are subject to taxation in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and various state and local jurisdictions.&amp;#160; We record liabilities for income tax contingencies based on our best estimate of the underlying exposures.&amp;#160; We are open for audit by the IRS for years after 2015 and
 generally
 by U.S. state tax jurisdictions after 2014.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;Reconciliations between the amounts computed by applying the U.S. federal statutory tax rate to loss before income taxes
 and income tax expense (benefit) follows (in thousands):&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;table align=center border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=width: 80%; color: #000000; font-family: 'Times New Roman';  2019 or 2018
 based on our analysis of tax positions taken on income tax returns filed.&amp;#160; Although we believe the amounts reflected in our tax returns substantially comply with applicable U.S. federal
 state

 when necessary
 to reduce that deferred tax asset if it is more likely than not that the related tax benefits will not be realized.&amp;#160; The realization of deferred tax assets can be affected by
 among other things
 the nature
 frequency and severity of current and cumulative losses
 forecasts of future profitability
 the length of statutory carryforward periods
 our experience with utilizing operating losses and tax credit carryforwards by jurisdiction
 and tax planning alternatives that may be available.&amp;#160; Due to the complexity of some of these uncertainties
 the ultimate resolution may result in a payment that may be different from current estimates of the tax liabilities.&amp;#160; If our estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate assessment
 an additional charge to expense would result.&amp;#160; If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be less than the recorded amounts
 the reversal of the liabilities may result in income tax benefits being recognized in the period when it is determined that the liabilities are no longer necessary.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;We recognize interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions

 Operating Lease

  

 Operating Lease

  

 Operating Lease
 Liability

  

 Finance Lease

  

 Finance Lease

  


 2019
 with adoption of ASU 2016-02 and related guidance (discussed further above under &amp;#8220;Recent Accounting Guidance&amp;#8221;).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;We lease certain buildings
 land and corporate office space under operating leases with monthly or annual rent payments.&amp;#160; We lease certain machinery and equipment under finance leases with monthly rent payments.&amp;#160; We determine if an arrangement is a lease at inception.&amp;#160; Operating lease assets are presented as operating lease right-of-use assets and the related liabilities are presented as operating lease liabilities in our consolidated balance sheets.&amp;#160; Finance lease right-of-use assets are included in property and equipment
 net
 and the related liabilities are included as finance lease liabilities in our consolidated balance sheets.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;We recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities based on the present value of the future minimum lease payments over the lease term
 beginning at the commencement date
 for leases exceeding a year.&amp;#160; Minimum lease payments include the fixed lease components of the lease and any variable rate payments that depend on an index
 initially measured using the index at the lease commencement date.&amp;#160; Lease terms may include options to renew when it is reasonably certain that we will exercise that option.&amp;#160; We combine lease and nonlease components and account for them as a single lease component.&amp;#160; Certain leases contain rent escalation clauses
 rent holidays
 capital improvement funding or other lease concessions.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;In determining our right-of-use assets and lease liabilities
 we apply a discount rate to the minimum lease payments within each lease.&amp;#160; When we cannot readily determine the discount rate implicit in a lease
 we utilize our incremental borrowing rate
 the rate of interest that we would incur to borrow
 on a collateralized basis over a similar term
 an amount equal to the lease payments in a similar economic environment.&amp;#160; To estimate the incremental borrowing rate
 we reference a market yield curve consistent with our assessment of our credit quality.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;We recognize operating lease expense related to the minimum lease payments on a straight-line basis over the lease term.&amp;#160; For finance leases
 we recognize amortization expense related to the minimum lease payments on a straight-line basis over the lease term while interest expense is recognized using the effective interest method.&amp;#160; Expense related to variable lease payments that do not depend on a rate or index and short-term rentals
 on leases with terms less than a year

text-indent: -9pt; margin-left: 18pt;&gt;Fixed leases cost&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #FFFFFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #FFFFFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right; width: 9%; background-color: #FFFFFF;&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;522&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #FFFFFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: top; width: 58%; background-color: rgb(204, 238, 255);&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-indent: -9pt; margin-left: 18pt;&gt;Variable lease cost&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; text-align: right; width: 9%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&lt;div style=color: #000000;&gt;132&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 nowrap=nowrap valign=bottom style=vertical-align: bottom; width: 1%; background-color: #CCEEFF;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td colspan=1 valign=bottom style=vertical-align: top; width: 58%; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); padding-bottom: 2px;&gt;&lt;div style=color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-indent: -9pt; margin-left: 9pt;&gt;Short-term lease cost


  

  

  

  


  


  


  


  


  


  


  


  


  


  


  

  


  

  


  


  


  


  

 Maturities

  

  

  


  


  

  

 Maturities

  


  

  

  

  

  

  


  


  



 the FASB issued guidance which changed the accounting for leases
&lt;font style=font-style: italic; color: #000000;&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;ASU No. 2016-02&lt;font style=font-style: italic;&gt;
 Leases &lt;/font&gt;(ASU 2016-02)&lt;font style=font-style: italic;&gt;.&lt;/font&gt;&amp;#160; &lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;On January 1
 2019
 we adopted the guidance
 and subsequent guidance related to the topic in ASU 2018-11
 using the modified retrospective method.&amp;#160; No adjustment was required to our retained earnings as of January 1
 2019.&amp;#160; &lt;/font&gt;Under prior GAAP
 the recognition
 measurement and presentation of expenses and cash flows arising from a lease depended primarily on the lease&amp;#8217;s classification as a finance or operating lease.&amp;#160; Under ASU 2016-02
 we recognize a right-of-use asset and a lease liability for both types of leases.&amp;#160; For finance leases
 we recognize amortization of the right-of-use asset separately from interest expense on the lease liability.&amp;#160; &lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;We elected the package of practical expedients in transition for leases that commenced prior to January 1
 2019
 and therefore did not &lt;/font&gt;reassess (i) whether any expired or existing contracts are
 or contain
 leases
 (ii) the lease classification for any expired or existing leases
 and (iii) initial direct costs for any existing leases.&amp;#160; We did not elect to use hindsight for transition when considering judgments and estimates such as assessments of lease options to extend
 or terminate
 a lease
 or to purchase the underlying asset.&amp;#160; &lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;We have no land easements.&amp;#160; For all asset classes
 we elected to (i) not recognize a right-of-use asset and lease liability for leases with a term of 12 months or less and (ii) not separate nonlease components from lease components
 and we have accounted for combined lease and nonlease components as a single lease component&lt;/font&gt;.&amp;#160; As of January 1
 2019
 we recorded operating lease right-of-use assets of $3.0 million and operating lease liabilities of $3.3 million
 with the difference being a reduction to existing liabilities.&amp;#160; The comparative information has not been restated and continues to be reported under the accounting standards in effect for those periods
 other than finance leases
 which are now separately classified and are no longer classified as long-term debt.&amp;#160; Additional&lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt; disclosures required by the guidance are presented within the &amp;#8220;Leases&amp;#8221; policy disclosure below and &lt;/font&gt;Note 10.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=text-align: justify;&gt;In June 2018
 the FASB issued ASU No. 2018-07
 &lt;font style=font-style: italic;&gt;Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Nonemployee Share-Based Payment Accounting &lt;/font&gt;(ASU 2018-07&lt;font style=font-style: italic;&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=color: #000000;&gt;.&amp;#160; The guidance was issued to simplify the accounting for share-based transactions by expanding the scope of Topic 718 from only being applicable to share-based payments to employees to also include share-based payment transactions for acquiring goods and services from nonemployees.&amp;#160; As a result
 nonemployee share-based transactions are measured by estimating the fair value of the equity instruments at the grant date
 taking into consideration the probability of satisfying performance conditions. We adopted ASU 2018-07 on January 1
 2019.&amp;#160; The guidance did not change the way we recognize expense for director awards.&amp;#160; Adoption of the standard only impacted the recognition of expense
 on a prospective basis
